title_content.content: Reliability-based evaluation of design code provisions for circular concrete-filled steel columns

paragraph_content.content: André T. Beck ∗, Walter L.A. de Oliveira, Silvana De Nardim, Ana L.H.C. ElDebs
Department of Structural Engineering, University of São Paulo, Av. Trabalhador Sancarlense, 400, 13566-590, São Carlos, SP, Brazil

title_content.content: a r t i c l e i n f o
a b s t r a c t

paragraph_content.content: This paper presents an investigation of design code provisions for steel-concrete composite columns. The study covers the national building codes of United States, Canada and Brazil, and the transnational EUROCODE. The study is based on experimental results of 93 axially loaded concrete-filled tubular steel columns. This includes 36 unpublished, full scale experimental results by the authors and 57 results from the literature. The error of resistance models is determined by comparing experimental results for ultimate loads with code-predicted column resistances. Regression analysis is used to describe the variation of model error with column slenderness and to describe model uncertainty. The paper shows that Canadian and European codes are able to predict mean column resistance, since resistance models of these codes present detailed formulations for concrete confinement by a steel tube. ANSI/AISC and Brazilian codes have limited allowance for concrete confinement, and become very conservative for short columns. Reliability analysis is used to evaluate the safety level of code provisions. Reliability analysis includes model error and other random problem parameters like steel and concrete strengths, and dead and live loads. Design code provisions are evaluated in terms of sufficient and uniform reliability criteria. Results show that the four design codes studied provide uniform reliability, with the Canadian code being best in achieving this goal. This is a result of a well balanced code, both in terms of load combinations and resistance model. The European code is less successful in providing uniform reliability, a consequence of the partial factors used in load combinations. The paper also shows that reliability indexes of columns designed according to European code can be as low as 2.2, which is quite below target reliability levels of EUROCODE.

In recent years, steel–concrete composite design has been experiencing increasing applications worldwide. In many cases, the choice for concrete-filled steel is based on the excellent resistance of this composite to seismic loading. This property is credited to the confinement effect of concrete by steel tube, to the ductility provided by the outer steel and to the great energy absorption capacity of the composite [1].

In addition to the sound mechanical properties, concrete-filled steel does not require formwork during construction and allows for a reduction of cross-sections when compared with reinforced concrete. Due to these advantages and increasing usage worldwide, steel concrete composites have been subject of intense research in recent years [2–11].
This paper addresses the safety of design code provisions for steel–concrete composite columns. The investigation covers the

national building codes of United States [12], Brazil [13] and Canada [14] and the transnational EUROCODE [15]. An outlook of these design-code provisions is presented in Section 2. Structural reliability theory is used to evaluate the safety of design code provisions for steel–concrete composite columns. Reliability theory has been extensively used in the calibration and evaluation of design code provisions [16,17].

The study is based on experimental results for 93 columns. This includes 36 columns tested by the authors [18] and 57 results obtained by other authors [7–10]. The study is limited to circular concrete-filled steel columns. Experimental results by the authors are presented in Section 3. Experimental results taken from the literature are briefly reviewed in Section 4. Section 5 addresses the error of code resistance models, by comparing code-predicted resistance to experimental results. Reliability analysis covering a wide range of design situations follows in Section 6. Results are presented in Section 7.

title_content.content: 2. Design code provisions for composite columns

paragraph_content.content: The main dimensioning equations for the four design code provisions considered in this paper are presented in this section. This
includes the American (ANSI/AISC) code [12], the Brazilian [13], the Canadian [14] and the EUROCODE [15]. Details of the formulations can of course be found in the corresponding code documents.

The design codes considered in this study present different expressions for the resistance of steel–concrete composite columns. However, they are all based on the sum of the contributions of concrete and steel to column resistance.
In the ANSI/AISC design code [12], design resistance of a composite column is given by:
is the partial factor applied to column resistance (equal to 0.75). The normal resistance

The major difference between the design codes, with a significant impact in the analyses to follow, is that European and Canadian codes provide detailed allowances for concrete confinement effects, whereas the ANSI and Brazilian codes have very limited (and constant) allowances. The gain in concrete resistance (due to confinement by the steel tube) is only
, following ANSI and Brazilian codes, whereas it can be as high as 5 or 10 times, following the European or Canadian codes. The consequences will be explored in the analysis to follow.

Table 1 shows the partial (resistance and load) factors used in the four design code provisions just described. Partial safety factors and characteristic resistance values are used in normal design situations, when a safety margin is to be created. When the actual (model) resistance is required, the safety margin is eliminated by setting partial factors to unity and by replacing characteristic values of material resistance by mean values. In order to distinguish the two situations, the design resistance (with safety margins) is denoted by
and actual resistance (without safety margins and with mean material values) is denoted by
. The actual resistance is required in two instances in this paper: first, when comparing design code (model) resistances with experimental results; second, in safety evaluation (Section 6).

paragraph_content.content: The present study is based on experimental results obtained for 36 circular concrete-filled steel tube columns of different configurations. The main parameter varied in these tests was the lengthto-diameter ratio
and 10} were tested. The columns were composed of steel tubes of
The columns were filled with concretes of mean compressive strengths o
and 105.45} MPa. These concretes were produced with commonly encountered materials and usual techniques of mixture and cure. Compressive strengths were obtained by testing cylindrical specimens
8 days after production. The elastic modulus was evaluated by means of the normative prescriptions.
Yield strength of the tubes was also evaluated by testing. For the tube with wall thickness
, a mean strength of 287 MPa was found, with a c.o.v. of
wall thickness tube, mean strength was 343 MPa and the c.o.v. was found to be

Testing of the columns was performed at the Structures Laboratory, São Carlos School of Engineering, University of São Paulo. An Instron 8506 testing machine was used for this purpose. This electronically controlled equipment allows static tests of up to
nominal load which can be applied to structural elements of large proportions.

The tested columns were instrumented with four linear variable differential transducers (LVDT), which were placed outside the columns with help of metal collars. Longitudinal displacements were measured as the mean of four transducers. Additionally, two
strain gauges were placed outside each column, and two were placed in a steel bar inside the concrete, allowing measurement of strains in both steel and concrete components of the composite column.

Centered axial loading was applied to the concrete and steel section of the columns and tests were conducted until failure. The failure of short columns was characterized by shear fracture of the concrete core, which was still confined by the steel tube. Slender columns failed due to global plastic buckling with no signs of local buckling of the steel tube.
Ultimate loads obtained for the 36 tested specimens are presented in Table 2, seventh column. The first six columns in Table 2 identify column details.
In order to obtain a complete picture of design code provisions for steel–concrete composite columns, experimental results from the literature were also considered in this study.
Giakoumelis and Lam [7] tested 15 concrete-filled tubular steel columns, with a diameter
ratio of approximately 2.6. Columns were filled with concretes of classes 30, 60 and 100 MPa. In order to study the effects of concrete confinement, wall thicknesses of
{3.75 to 5} mm were considered. 13 results by the authors were incorporated in this study.
Sakino et al. [8] tested 36 columns, but only 12 had wall thicknesses within acceptable limits for the design codes considered herein
and 6.47} mm. These columns had slenderness ratios
{108, 122 and 149} mm. Concrete resistances were equal to

Ultimate loads for the 57 columns taken from the literature and considered in this paper are presented in Table 3, including details of each column.

The four design code provisions described in Section 2 were used to predict the strength of the tested columns (Sections 3 and 4), using mean material strengths and unitary partial resistance factors. Experimental results are compared with code resistance curves in Fig. 1. Results are shown in non-dimensional form, in terms of reduced slenderness ratio λ and resistance reduction function
for the different codes, and the resistance reduction factor obtained by dividing experimental column resistance by the nominal cross-section resistance, following each code. Slenderness ratios
are also given by individual code provisions. For the ANSI/AISC code, it is calculated as:
Fig. 1 shows that, for small slenderness ratios
, the European and Canadian resistance curves describe the mean of experimental results. The American and Brazilian resistance curves are
quite conservative, yielding a resistance nearly

lower than the mean of experimental results. This difference between the codes can be interpreted in view of the different allowances for the effects of concrete confinement. Since the allowance for concrete confinement is minimal in the American and Brazilian codes, the predicted resistance is well below experimental values. For European and Canadian codes, the detailed formulation for concrete confinement is able to reproduce the mean of experimental results.

, the four design codes are slightly conservative. Experimental results are scarce, but their scatter is clearly smaller. This is understandable, since the mechanics of slender columns is better modeled (elastic buckling).
In order to compare theoretical resistance models of the design codes with experimental results, a model error (ME) variable is introduced:

This has also been called the professional factor by Ellingwood and Galambos [17]. Samples of the model error random variable are obtained, for each design code provision, from the 93 available experimental results. These are presented in Table 2 (columns 8 to 11) for the 36 experimental results by the authors and in Table 3 for the 57 results from the literature.

Results show that the model error variable is dependent on the slenderness ratio, as suggested by Fig. 1. A non-linear regression analysis was performed, in order to describe the model error variable:

Resistance random variables with significant uncertainty include the model error variable and material parameters like the steel’s yield strength and concrete compressive strength. Statistical moments and probability distributions of these variables are taken from refs. [17,19] and are shown in Table 5.

Model error affects reliability of the columns in two ways. A greater-than-one mean or bias (the case of ANSI and Brazilian codes) reveals an additional safety margin, which reduces failure probabilities. A smaller-than-one mean or bias produces an increase in failure probabilities. Model error uncertainty, reflected in random variable
Steel and concrete strength parameters were taken from the literature, as referenced in Table 5. Three characteristic values of steel strength are considered in the analysis:
S _ { y k } = \left\{ 2 0 0 , 2 5 0 , 3 0 0 \right\} \mathrm { M P a }
. Four characteristic concrete strengths were considered:
{15, 30, 50, 70} MPa. Other resistance parameters could also have been modeled as random variables. However, these are considered to have a smaller importance in column safety.

paragraph_content.content: In order for the reliability analysis to reflect the range of design conditions covered by the codes in study, a range of design parameters has to be considered. As described in the previous lines, in this study 3 values of the steel yield strength, 4 values of concrete strength and 7 load ratios are considered. Moreover, the study considers 5 values of slenderness:
{100, 200} mm. In total, 1680 column configurations are covered in the reliability analysis.
The resulting slenderness ratios considered in the study are well within the range allowed by the design codes. The European and Brazilian codes, for instance, allow columns with
. For the columns analyzed herein, slenderness ratios are in the range
. This range of slenderness ratios avoids modeling difficulties encountered for

The limit state function for the reliability analysis is:

content.math_content: g (\mathbf {X}) = N _ {R S} \left(X _ {1}, X _ {2}\right) \cdot X _ {3} - X _ {4} - X _ {5} \tag {16}

paragraph_content.content: is the model error variable, ME(λ);

For each of the 1680 column configurations and for each design code, column resistance is evaluated by code provisions (Eqs. (1)– (12)), loads are evaluated from Eq. (15) and the reliability index is calculated using limit state equation (16). Reliability indexes are evaluated using the first order reliability method (FORM) [20]. Reliability analysis is made with the software Mathematica 6.0, using routines developed by Beck [21]. Each set of results contains the solution of 6720 reliability problems.
Reliability analysis results are presented in this section. Fig. 4 shows the range of reliability index

results for the four design codes considered as function of load ratios. Two sets of results are shown in this figure. The continuous lines represent actual column reliability, since these results include the model error random variable. The dashed lines are obtained when model error is not considered, and are shown only to illustrate the impact of model error in reliability results. Each result set corresponds to two lines, showing the range of reliability indexes obtained. In other words, the smallest and largest
’s amongst all analyzed columns are shown in Fig. 4 (and in the figures to follow).
Fig. 4 shows that the model error has significant impact in reliability, especially for small load ratios. This result can be related to

image_caption.content: Fig. 5. Reliability sensitivity coefficients of code-designed columns as function of load ratio.

paragraph_content.content: reliability sensitivity coefficients, shown in Fig. 5. This figure also shows the range of results (largest and smallest sensitivity coefficients) among all column configurations analyzed. Sensitivity coefficients represent the contribution of each random variable in failure probabilities. Load variables appear with negative coefficients, whereas resistance variables have positive coefficients.
It can be seen is Figs. 4 and 5 that for small load ratios
0.5), the most important contribution to failure probabilities comes from model error, followed by concrete resistance
. For larger load ratios, the live load L plays an increasingly dominant role. For small load ratios, model error reduces reliability indexes for all codes.
, the model error has virtually no impact in EUROCODE results. This happens because the resistance model becomes conservative, with the model error mean greater than one (1.05 in limit with

, but model error variance still impacts adversely on reliability indexes. The net result is no impact of model error in reliability results. Similar interpretation applies for Canadian code and large load ratios, where a limited impact of the model error is observed.

For the ANSI/AISC and Brazilian codes, and for large load ratios, a consideration of model error increases the upper range of reliability indexes. This happens due to conservativeness of these codes in the design of short columns. This can be better seen in Figs. 6 and 7, where the range of reliability indexes is shown in terms of column slenderness.
In Figs. 6 and 7, the range of reliability indexes is shown in terms of column slenderness
(Fig. 7). In these figures, it can be seen that, for small slenderness ratios

and for ANSI/AISC and Brazilian codes, model error has a significant and positive impact in reliability indexes. This is clearly due to the conservativeness of these codes, for short columns, as observed in Figs. 1 and 3. For small slenderness, the impact of model error in European and Canadian codes is the opposite, reducing reliability indexes. For large slenderness ratios, the impact of model error is negative for all codes. This is due to the contribution of model error uncertainty.

table_caption.content: Table 6 Summary of reliability index results.

paragraph_content.content: Table 6 summarizes reliability index results obtained for the four design codes studied. The table shows the minimum, maximum and the range of reliability indexes obtained for each code. Clearly, such limits are not absolute: they reflect the range of column configurations considered in the reliability analysis, which are believed to reflect the universe of practical column configuration covered by each design code.

Two criteria can be used to evaluate design code provisions in terms of reliability: structural design codes should provide sufficient and uniform reliability over the range of designs covered by the code [17].

The sufficiency criterion requires a definition of an acceptable level of safety. Reliability indexes used in code calibration work should be useful in this purpose. The American and Canadian codes were designed for a target reliability index
load combination [17]. Fig. 4 shows that the ANSI/AISC code meets the target (conservatively). The Canadian code falls slightly below this target, but is always above 2.4. The authors ignore target
values used in the calibration of EUROCODE, but its Annex C [15] recommends a minimum

for 50 years and consequence class 2 (residential and office buildings). This level of reliability is not achieved by the EUROCODE, as shown in the figures. Our results show reliability indexes as low as
. For the Brazilian code, reliability indexes are always above 2.4.

The four design codes studied seem to provide reasonably uniform reliability indexes, as shown in Fig. 4 and Table 6. The Canadian code is best at achieving this goal, with a reliability index range of 1.884. This can be compared with the range of nearly 2.2 achieved by Brazilian and ANSI/AISC codes, and with a

Fig. 7. Reliability index bounds as function of slenderness ratio, for
; with (cont. line) and without (dashed line) consideration of model error.

paragraph_content.content: range of 2.8 for the EUROCODE. The interpretation of these results involves two main points. In terms of load combinations, the ratio of dead to live load factors of ANSI/AISC (
) seem to be better balanced, at least in light of the calibrations performed by Ellingwood and Galambos [17]. For the Brazilian and European codes, these ratios are greater
, hence less likely to reflect differences in the uncertainties of L and

of reliabilities. The uniformness of reliability indexes for the ANSI/AISC code is no better because of the second point: the quality of the resistance model. ANSI/AISC (and Brazilian) design codes have very limited allowance for concrete confinement effects, resulting in overly conservative resistance models. This results in large reliability indexes for designs involving small amounts of live load
, as seen in Fig. 4. Hence, the best performance of the Canadian code, in providing uniform reliability, can be

page_header_content.content: A.T. Beck et al. / Engineering Structures 31 (2009) 2299–2308

paragraph_content.content: attributed to the good balance between dead and live load factors, and to a well calibrated column resistance model.

This paper presented an investigation of design code provisions for circular concrete-filled steel columns. The study included experimental results for 93 columns: 36 novel experimental results by the authors, and 57 results from the literature. Experimental results were compared with design provisions by the ANSI/AISC, European, Brazilian and Canadian codes, resulting in statistics of model error for column resistance.

Regression analysis was used to describe the variation of model errors in terms of column slenderness, and to describe model error uncertainty. Resistance models of European and Canadian codes provide detailed allowances for concrete confinement by the steel tube. As a result, these models are able to predict mean column resistances. ANSI/AISC and Brazilian codes have a limited and constant allowance for concrete confinement, and become overly conservative for very short columns (up to
). For large slenderness ratios, concrete confinement is minimal, column behavior is mainly elastic, and resistance models of the four design codes become slightly conservative.

Reliability analyses were performed for a large number of column configurations, covering the range of design code application. Reliability analyses revealed that model error is quite relevant for column safety, especially for small load ratios. Consideration of model error resulted in increased reliability of short columns designed according to ANSI/AISC and Brazilian codes, due to conservative column resistances predicted by these codes. For short columns designed by European or Canadian codes, consideration of model error produces a reduction of reliability indexes. For slender columns designed according to any of the four codes, model error leads to reduction of reliability indexes.

Design code provisions were evaluated in terms of sufficient and uniform reliability criteria. The Canadian code provided the best results, in terms of these criteria. Reliability indexes are larger than 2.40 and smaller than 4.28, resulting in a maximum range of 1.88. This result can be credited to a well balanced resistance model (with detailed allowance for concrete confinement), and to the partial load factors used in the Canadian code. The resistance model of EUROCODE provided good estimates of (mean) column resistance, but the scatter of reliability indexes was significantly larger than for the Canadian code. Reliability indexes of columns designed following EUROCODE were found to be as low as 2.2. This value is well below target reliability indexes presented in EUROCODE’s Annex C.
The authors kindly acknowledge financial support of this research project by the agencies CNPq (National Council for Research and Development) and FAPESP (São Paulo State Foundation for Research).
